# Space Law On Space Station 14, stations operate under abbreviated space law. All crew, passengers, and visitors aboard the station are expected to follow these laws.
[color=#ffa500]Foreign intruders, such as nuclear operatives, ninjas, and pirates, are not protected under space law. Traitors, as they are crew and not intruders, [bold]are protected by space law.[/bold][/color]
[bold]Space Law is not the server rules,[/bold] but some rules reference Space Law and require it to be followed by certain people or to some degree.
## Treatment Of Prisoners Prisoners still have certain rights that must be upheld by law enforcement: - Prisoners must be granted adequate medical care. - Prisoners must be allowed access to basic communications equipment (Radios); [color=#ffa500]this can be revoked if the prisoner abuses it.[/color] - Prisoners must be granted clothing, food, water, shelter and safety. If the brig is no longer safe, confinement must be established in another location. - Prisoners must be given access to legal counsel during an interrogation if requested and available. - Prisoners must be given their shift mandated PDA after confinement has finished, [color=#ffa500]unless there is solid proof of PDA tampering (IE, an open Uplink).[/color] In case of tampering, the PDA is to be secured and replaced with a new unit. - Prisoners must be granted freedom of movement, and should not be restrained with handcuffs or other devices after incarceration unless they have demonstrated intent to harm themself or others. Similarly, any prisoners held for permanent confinement should be held in the communal brig ("Perma"), and should not be confined to a solitary cell unless they have demonstrated a safety risk to themselves.
## Search and Seizure A personnel search is a seizure of the objects in a person's backpack, hands, coat, belt, and pockets. If any contraband is found during a search, the officer may choose to further the search into a detainment, or simply confiscate the restricted items. [color=#ffa500]After the search is conducted, all legal items are to be returned to the person.[/color] A crewmate may decline any search conducted without probable cause or a warrant while the alert level is green. [color=#1e90ff]However, if the alert level is blue or above, all personnel searches cannot be declined.[/color]
A departmental search is the sweep of an entire area or department for contraband. It is recommended that the officers be extremely thorough, checking all lockers, crates, and doors. [color=#ffa500]These can only be done with a warrant signed by the department head, Head of Security, or highest-ranking command staff, which is typically the Captain.[/color]
## Implantation Any prisoner in custody can be subjected to implantation or implant removal procedures, within reason. The process of adding an implant should not prolong the detainee's brig sentence, meaning you can not hold them longer to administer the implant. A former inmate can be requested to undergo implantation at a later point in time if they fit the circumstances during their confinement, and they must comply.
The following have been listed out with special circumstances; anything not in this list can still be applied, given proper legal context. A prisoner can still receive implantation procedures without meeting the circumstances if they give their clear permission.
[color=#a4885c][bold]Tracking Implants:[/bold][/color] Trackers can be applied to any suspect that has been convicted of a violent crime ("(V)" suffixed crimes).
[color=#a4885c][bold]Mindshields:[/bold][/color] Mindshields may be implanted in retaliation to known or suspected union activity, or other forms of large-scale crew mutiny. This use of implants should only done during an active [color=pink]Code Pink[/color], but in this situation, can be done freely without prior authorization. You may hold a prisoner until you finish issuing mindshields, so long as it is done in a timely fashion. Failure to comply with being mindshielded can be used as evidence to charge Treason.
## Implant Removal A suspect can be forced to receive implant removal if there is reasonable proof that they have been implanted, such as an officer seeing them use one, or their DNA being on a discarded injector. Unlike the implantation procedure, a prisoner may be held indefinitely until they comply with the procedure, as long as security is actively making attempts to perform it. As with implanting, if an inmate gives their clear permission, implant removal can proceed without proof.
## Sentencing From a server rules perspective, [color=#1e90ff]security officers are only responsible for ensuring that they only place sentences over 15 minutes where space law would allow permanent confinement.[/color] The Warden should be issuing all sentences when possible. As long as those requirements are met, security officers not giving inappropriate sentence lengths is considered an in-character issue, not a rule issue.
The Captain, Head of Security, and Warden are responsible for ensuring security officers place appropriate sentences that follow space law. [color=#ffa500]If they are aware of an inappropriate punishment, including excessively long sentences, or inappropriate confiscation of materials, then they must work to correct that mistake.[/color] Unreasonable failures, as determined by game admins, of the Captain, Head of Security, or Warden to ensure space law is followed can be considered a rule issue, rather than an in-character issue.
Use common sense and humanity when issuing punishments. [color=#1e90ff]You should not always seek out the highest punishment you can. You don't have to always give the maximum time, or always look to demote someone.[/color] [color=#ffa500]Cooperative prisoners should have their sentences reduced.[/color] Always take in account the severity and only charge for what is needed for someone to learn their lesson.
[color=#a4885c]Stackable Crimes:[/color] Crimes are to be considered 'stackable' in the sense that if you charge someone with two or more different crimes, you should combine the times you would give them for each crime. Linked crimes, shown in matching colors and suffixes on the Quick Crime Guide, can not be stacked and instead override each other; you should pick the highest crime that matches the case.
- [bold]Example:[/bold] A suspect has committed a 2-01 (possession: major) and a 3-01 (possession: syndicate). The maximum sentence here would be 10 minutes due to them being linked crimes, and 3-01 is the greater crime. - [bold]Example 2:[/bold] A suspect commits a 3-04 (Secure trespassing) and a 3-06 (manslaughter). Those crimes stack since they are not linked crimes. You could sentence for a maximum of 20 minutes, but context matters heavily, and maximum sentences should only be used for the worst offenders.
[color=#a4885c]Repeat Offenders:[/color] Repeated crimes are when someone is released for a crime [color=#1e90ff]and then goes to commit the same crime, within the same shift.[/color] Repeated crimes can be charged with tacked-on time; for example, first repeat: 3:00, second repeat: 6:00, third repeat: permanent confinement. It should be noted that each tacked-on time is directly linked to one type of crime, so, for example, if someone does their first repeat of trespass and petty theft, you can charge them with an extra 6 minutes.
[color=#a4885c]Accessory, Attempting, And Intention:[/color] If someone intentionally, knowingly, and substantially assists someone in enacting a crime they can be charged with the relevant crimes, such as an engineer giving someone who says they are going to break into an area a full set of tools. The same goes for a clear and solid attempt at a crime, or a person who shows clear intent to act out a crime, such as a Syndicate nuclear operative arming a nuke but getting arrested before it goes off: they can still be charged with terrorism. This does not apply to crimes that have an attempted listing already, such as attempted murder.
## Normal Punishments - [color=#a4885c]Warning:[/color] For minor crimes: fix the issue, then warn the person not to attempt the crime again. If they still proceed to do it at a later date, escalate to confinement. - [color=#a4885c]Confinement:[/color] The typical punishment: being confined in a cell for a temporary amount of time according to the crimes. - [color=#a4885c]Demotion:[/color] This entails removing all departmental gear they have on their person, and revoking the involved department access from their ID. This requires the Captain's or involved department head's approval. Demotions should only be issued if the person poses a threat to their own department, or are in a position where they have/can abuse their job's gear to commit further crimes.
## Major Punishments - [color=#a4885c]Permanent Confinement:[/color] Being held in the permanent brig for the remaining duration of the shift. A person is eligible for permanent confinement if their timed sentence exceeds 15 minutes. Any persons subject to this punishment are required to be transported in cuffs to Central Command at the end of the shift. [color=#1e90ff]A permanent prisoner can not be deprived of anything covered by the section "Treatment Of Prisoners".[/color] - [color=#a4885c]Execution:[/color] Within reason, a prisoner who has been given the death sentence may pick how they wish to be killed; common methods are firing line, lethal injection, exile, and high voltage electrocution. Another alternate method of "execution" is the process of placing a staff's mind into a borg, this is allowed so long as it is lawful. Execution can only be issued with the approval of the highest ranked staff member, ideally the Captain; if the Head of Security is acting Captain, or there is no acting Captain, all heads of staff are to hold a vote on the matter. [color=#ffa500]Executions must be announced to the station ahead of time via the communication console.[/color]
